comments.body: I don't think this dependency should be under host. Since `highfive` is only a user-build-time dependency of this header-only library, the user should be free to use whatever version of `highfive` it wants. Setting it as `host` dependency would link it to a specific `highfive` version.

> Setting it as host dependency would link it to a specific highfive version.

It won't as [highfive](https://github.com/conda-forge/highfive-feedstock/blob/master/recipe/meta.yaml) doesn't use `run_exports`.
OK! But then still it is not clear to me why one needs it at the `host`. Also I still think one *also* needs it at `build` (as it is needed at build time to construct this project's CMake target)

`build` supposed to be for tools related to the build system itself, like `make`, `cmake` and the compilers that will need to run on the build machine's architecture.

`host` is for thing actually used by the build that will end up being used on the final runtime architecture.

The `host` and `build` environments are stacked when building so files from both are available.

That is clear, thanks! So what I should do I should do only e.g. for `hdf5` that is pinned. And since `highfive` is not pinned, nor has `hdf5` as host dependency I'll be fine here in terms of being `hdf5` version independent?

Yes, if you were linking against `hdf5` you would put it in `host` directly and then the appropriate pins would magically appear (assuming `run_exports` is present in `hdf5`). If it's not explicitly in `host` then it's seen as an implementation detail of `highfive` that has nothing to do with this recipe. You can override this behaviour using `ignore_run_exports` (or something similar).
